issue.title: Regex matching errors when using \W character class and /i option
issue.body: see: http://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/4044

comments.body:
Also related:
http://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/7533
http://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/7534

I tested several patterns with Perl 5.14 and 5.16:

```
                                    Perl 5.14  Perl 5.16
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iu)\w/            → match
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iu)[\w]/          → match
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iu)\W/            → unmatch
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iu)[\W]/          → unmatch

"\x{17f}" =~ /(?ia)\w/            → unmatch ★
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?ia)[\w]/          → match ★   unmatch
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?ia)\W/            → match
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?ia)[\W]/          → match

"s" =~ /(?ia)\w/                  → match
"s" =~ /(?ia)[\w]/                → match
"s" =~ /(?ia)\W/                  → unmatch
"s" =~ /(?ia)[\W]/                → unmatch

"\x{17f}" =~ /(?ia)\p{ASCII}/     → unmatch
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?ia)[\p{ASCII}]/   → unmatch
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?ia)\P{ASCII}/     → match
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?ia)[\P{ASCII}]/   → match

"s" =~ /(?ia)\p{ASCII}/           → match
"s" =~ /(?ia)[\p{ASCII}]/         → match
"s" =~ /(?ia)\P{ASCII}/           → unmatch
"s" =~ /(?ia)[\P{ASCII}]/         → unmatch

"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iaa)\w/           → unmatch
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iaa)[\w]/         → unmatch
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iaa)\W/           → match
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iaa)[\W]/         → match
```

★: Be careful with these results.

Other test patterns:

```
                                    Perl 5.14  Perl 5.16
# LATIN SMALL LETTER LONG S
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?u)[[:lower:]]/    → match
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?a)[[:lower:]]/    → unmatch ★
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?aa)[[:lower:]]/   → unmatch

"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iu)[[:lower:]]/   → match
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?ia)[[:lower:]]/   → match ★   unmatch
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iaa)[[:lower:]]/  → unmatch

# KELVIN SIGN
"\x{212a}" =~ /(?u)[[:upper:]]/   → match
"\x{212a}" =~ /(?a)[[:upper:]]/   → unmatch ★
"\x{212a}" =~ /(?aa)[[:upper:]]/  → unmatch

"\x{212a}" =~ /(?iu)[[:upper:]]/  → match
"\x{212a}" =~ /(?ia)[[:upper:]]/  → match ★   unmatch
"\x{212a}" =~ /(?iaa)[[:upper:]]/ → unmatch

# LATIN SMALL LETTER SHARP S (eszett)
"\x{df}" =~ /(?u)[[:lower:]]/     → match
"\x{df}" =~ /(?a)[[:lower:]]/     → unmatch ★
"\x{df}" =~ /(?aa)[[:lower:]]/    → unmatch

"\x{df}" =~ /(?iu)[[:lower:]]/    → match
"\x{df}" =~ /(?ia)[[:lower:]]/    → unmatch ★
"\x{df}" =~ /(?iaa)[[:lower:]]/   → unmatch
```

Perl 5.14 has some inconsistency, but they are fixed with Perl 5.16.
Maybe, it is better to use Perl 5.16 or later as a reference.

test script for onigmo:
https://gist.github.com/k-takata/85cf4de23d8194b2da34

More test patterns with Perl 5.16:

```
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iu)[^\w]/    → unmatch
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?ia)[^\w]/    → match
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iaa)[^\w]/   → match

"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iu)[^s]/     → unmatch
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?ia)[^s]/     → unmatch
"\x{17f}" =~ /(?iaa)[^s]/    → match

"\x{212a}" =~ /(?iu)[^\w]/   → unmatch
"\x{212a}" =~ /(?ia)[^\w]/   → match
"\x{212a}" =~ /(?iaa)[^\w]/  → match

"\x{212a}" =~ /(?iu)[^k]/    → unmatch
"\x{212a}" =~ /(?ia)[^k]/    → unmatch
"\x{212a}" =~ /(?iaa)[^k]/   → match
```

Details of this bug in Japanese.

# 現象

`(?ia)\w` と `(?ia)[\w]` の動作が異なる。
前者は ASCII の範囲内にしかマッチしないのに対し、後者は U+017F ("ſ" , LATIN SMALL LETTER LONG S), U+212a ("K", KELVIN SIGN) にもマッチしてしまう。
ASCII フラグ `(?a)` が指定されている場合、`\w` は ASCII の範囲内にしかマッチすべきではないが、文字クラスの中に入れると ASCII の範囲外にもマッチしてしまっている。
他に同様のものとしては、`\p{ASCII}`, `[[:ascii:]]` (`(?a)` に非依存) や、それ以外の POSIX クラス (`(?a)` 指定時のみ) がある。

## 影響するバージョン
- Ruby 1.9.1 ~ 1.9.3 に組み込みの Oniguruma 5.9.x  
  （オリジナルの Oniguruma 5.9.x は、`\w` は Unicode の範囲でマッチするため、U+017F, U+212a は元々マッチする。）
- Onigmo 5.10.0 ~ 5.14.2

# 原因

ignore case フラグ `(?i)` が指定されている場合、文字クラスをパースする際に、文字プロパティーやPOSIXクラスを個々の文字に展開し、次に case fold を行い、大文字小文字を展開した文字クラスを作成する。(E.g. `(?ia)[[:upper:]]` → `(?i)[A-Z]` → `[A-Za-z]`)
その際、一部の文字プロパティーなどは ASCII の範囲を超えて case fold を行ってはいけないにもかかわらず、それを行ってしまっている。

# 対策

文字クラスをパースして、文字プロパティーやPOSIXクラスを個々の文字に展開する際、ASCII の範囲を超えて case fold を行ってよいかを判定し、行ってよい文字だけを集めた文字クラス(`asc_cc`)を別に用意する。
元の文字クラスを case fold する際に、個々の文字が `asc_cc` に含まれているかを判定し、含まれていなければ ASCII の範囲を超えた case fold は行わないようにする。

`"こんにちは" =~ /\n?\z/` didn't match.

  http://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/8210

issue.title: look-behind does not take Unicode case-folding into account
issue.body:
Originally reported in https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/pull/17#issuecomment-18537525 .

```
>> /(?:\u{149})a/ui =~ "[\u{2bc}na]"  # Unicode case-folding match is in effect.
=> 1
>> /(?<=\u{149})a/ui =~ "[\u{2bc}na]"  # But look-behind does not take account of it.
=> nil
```

comments.body: Fixed in `devel-6.0` branch. Closing.

timeline.body: Fixed in `devel-6.0` branch. Closing.

issue.title: Deeply nested capture groups cause stack overflow

repository.name: Onigmo
repository.description: Onigmo is a regular expressions library forked from Oniguruma.

issue.body:
How to reproduce:

``` python
from testpy import *
# import onigmo
# set_encoding("UTF-8")
# set_output_encoding()
x2("(" * 32767 + "a" + ")" * 32767, "a", 0, 1)
```

Related: ~~#18~~ #24

This also occurs on Oniguruma 6.1.1.
Cc: @kkos

issue.body:
Oniguruma 5.9.4 was released on 2013/04/04.
see: http://www.geocities.jp/kosako3/oniguruma/

I have already imported Oniguruma 5.9.4 into the [oniguruma branch](https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/tree/oniguruma), but not merged into the master branch.

issue.title: Backwards search not respecting range

comments.body:
It seems to be caused by this #ifdef block: https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/blob/754f936272289460555c783211211ffda7857302/regexec.c#L4176
I don't know why this block is needed. I'll look into it more closely.

BTW, I think the expected result is `2-3`.

Hmm, the #ifdef block was added with Oniguruma 5.7.0.

Copied from the HISTORY:

```
2007/04/27: Version 5.7.0

2007/04/20: [spec] add config USE_MATCH_RANGE_IS_COMPLETE_RANGE.
2007/04/20: [impl] refactoring in match_at().
```

Note: `USE_MATCH_RANGE_IS_COMPLETE_RANGE` was changed to `USE_MATCH_RANGE_MUST_BE_INSIDE_OF_SPECIFIED_RANGE` with Oniguruma 5.9.0.

Thanks for looking into this.

Does this mean that defining `USE_MATCH_RANGE_MUST_BE_INSIDE_OF_SPECIFIED_RANGE` should return a match of `2-3`?

I tried to define it in `regexec.c:33` but got unchanged result.

> Does this mean that defining `USE_MATCH_RANGE_MUST_BE_INSIDE_OF_SPECIFIED_RANGE` should return a match of `2-3`?

Yes, I think so. But currently the result is `3-4` as you reported.

After applying the following patch, the result becomes `2-3` when `USE_MATCH_RANGE_MUST_BE_INSIDE_OF_SPECIFIED_RANGE` is defined.
(If it is not defined, the result becomes `3-6`.)

``` diff
--- a/regexec.c
+++ b/regexec.c
@@ -4173,11 +4173,6 @@ onig_search_gpos(regex_t* reg, const UChar* str, const UChar* end,
     }
   }
   else {  /* backward search */
-#ifdef USE_MATCH_RANGE_MUST_BE_INSIDE_OF_SPECIFIED_RANGE
-    if (orig_start < end)
-      orig_start += enclen(reg->enc, orig_start); /* is upper range */
-#endif
-
     if (reg->optimize != ONIG_OPTIMIZE_NONE) {
       UChar *low, *high, *adjrange, *sch_start;

```

I'm concerning about side effects caused by this patch. More tests are needed.

timeline.body:

I don't know why this block is needed. I'll look into it more closely.

BTW, I think the expected result is `2-3`.

issue.title: Add tests for backward search

repository.name: Onigmo
repository.description: Onigmo is a regular expressions library forked from Oniguruma.

issue.body:
Currently we don't have any tests for backward search.

Related: #22

timeline.body:
Hmm, the #ifdef block was added with Oniguruma 5.7.0.

Copied from the HISTORY:

```
2007/04/27: Version 5.7.0

2007/04/20: [spec] add config USE_MATCH_RANGE_IS_COMPLETE_RANGE.
2007/04/20: [impl] refactoring in match_at().
```

Note: `USE_MATCH_RANGE_IS_COMPLETE_RANGE` was changed to `USE_MATCH_RANGE_MUST_BE_INSIDE_OF_SPECIFIED_RANGE` with Oniguruma 5.9.0.

Thanks for looking into this.

Does this mean that defining `USE_MATCH_RANGE_MUST_BE_INSIDE_OF_SPECIFIED_RANGE` should return a match of `2-3`?

I tried to define it in `regexec.c:33` but got unchanged result.

> Does this mean that defining `USE_MATCH_RANGE_MUST_BE_INSIDE_OF_SPECIFIED_RANGE` should return a match of `2-3`?

Yes, I think so. But currently the result is `3-4` as you reported.

After applying the following patch, the result becomes `2-3` when `USE_MATCH_RANGE_MUST_BE_INSIDE_OF_SPECIFIED_RANGE` is defined.
(If it is not defined, the result becomes `3-6`.)

``` diff
--- a/regexec.c
+++ b/regexec.c
@@ -4173,11 +4173,6 @@ onig_search_gpos(regex_t* reg, const UChar* str, const UChar* end,
     }
   }
   else {  /* backward search */
-#ifdef USE_MATCH_RANGE_MUST_BE_INSIDE_OF_SPECIFIED_RANGE
-    if (orig_start < end)
-      orig_start += enclen(reg->enc, orig_start); /* is upper range */
-#endif
-
     if (reg->optimize != ONIG_OPTIMIZE_NONE) {
       UChar *low, *high, *adjrange, *sch_start;

```

I'm concerning about side effects caused by this patch. More tests are needed.

issue.title: segmation fault occurs when many groups are used
issue.body:
see: https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/8716

> WindowsとOS Xで検証しました。
> - 再現手順 ruby 2.0.0p247 (2013-06-27) [x64-mingw32]

``` Ruby
a="()"
(32767.times{a<<'()'}
eval "/#{a}/=~''"
```

> - 再現手順 ruby 2.0.0p0 (2013-02-24 revision 39474) [x86_64-darwin12.2.1]

``` Ruby
a="()"
(1<<21).times{a<<'()'}
eval "/#{a}/=~''"
```

> regexec.c:match_at()で呼ばれるSTACK_INITがサイズを考慮せずにxallocaしているため、スタックオーバーフローしています。

comments.body: It seems that b9fba1d causes random crashes with multithread settings.

Oops, still SEGV occurs.
There were two causes with this issue.
1. Using `alloca()` may cause stack overflow when allocating very large area. (Already fixed.)
2. Group number is managed by `MemNumType` which is `short int`. Thus, the number become negative if the number of group exceeds 32767. It may cause access errors. (Not fixed yet.)

Should Onigmo support more than 32767 groups?
Now the maximum number of capture groups is explicitly limited to 32767 (`ONIG_MAX_CAPTURE_GROUP_NUM`).

timeline.body: It seems that b9fba1d causes random crashes with multithread settings.

Should Onigmo support more than 32767 groups?
Now the maximum number of capture groups is explicitly limited to 32767 (`ONIG_MAX_CAPTURE_GROUP_NUM`).

issue.title: Use Volnitsky's substring search algorithm?
issue.body:
see: http://volnitsky.com/project/str_search/

Volnitsky's algorithm seems about 2x-4x faster than BMH or Sunday's quick search algorithm.
- Can it support Unicode (UTF-8, UTF-16 and UTF-32)?
- Can it support multibyte encoding like Shift_JIS? The same byte can be appear in leading byte and trailing byte.

issue.title: Two warnings use incorrect source file and line when found in instance_eval
issue.body:
This is ruby bug [#9344](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/9344):

```
$ cat 9344.rb
code = <<-RUBY
x = /]]/
y = /[a-z]+*/
z = /[a-z]**/
RUBY
instance_eval code, 'foo.rb'
$ ruby 9344.rb
foo.rb:1: warning: regular expression has ']' without escape: /]]/
9344.rb:6: warning: nested repeat operator + and * was replaced with '*': /[a-z]+*/
9344.rb:6: warning: redundant nested repeat operator: /[a-z]**/
```

My solution was to stop using `onig_verb_warn` and instead use `onig_syntax_warn`. These are the last two references to `onig_verb_warn`, so then that function can be deleted too.

I attached a patch to the ruby bug. Should I open a pull request here?

comments.body:
Ruby uses customized version of Onigmo. Currently, the customized version is stored in the branch `tmp/ruby-2.0.x`.
(You can see the differences between the branches `master` and `tmp/ruby-2.0.x` here: https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/compare/master...tmp;ruby-2.0.x#files_bucket )

Warning functions are also customized for Ruby. Your patch is only needed for the branch `tmp/ruby-2.0.x`.
`onig_verb_warn` is still used in the master branch. So, it is not a good idea to remove `onig_verb_warn` and related codes. Isn't it enough to change inside the function `set_quantifier`?

`onig_verb_warn` is used for [verbose warning function](https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/blob/master/doc/API#L40).
Removing them cause API incompatibility.

Ah, I understand! Both `onig_set_verb_warn_func` and `onig_verb_warn` are part of the public API, so we should not delete them. Thanks for the analysis.

I just opened #32 that is a smaller fix, only changing those two references to instead use `onig_syntax_warn`.

(You can see the differences between the branches `master` and `tmp/ruby-2.0.x` here: https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/compare/master...tmp;ruby-2.0.x#files_bucket )

`onig_verb_warn` is still used in the master branch. So, it is not a good idea to remove `onig_verb_warn` and related codes. Isn't it enough to change inside the function `set_quantifier`?

`onig_verb_warn` is used for [verbose warning function](https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/blob/master/doc/API#L40).
Removing them cause API incompatibility.

issue.title: warnings occur when compile with MinGW
issue.body:
```
regcomp.c: In function 'disable_noname_group_capture':
regcomp.c:2020:3: warning: implicit declaration of function 'alloca' [-Wimplicit-function-declaration]
   map = (GroupNumRemap* )xalloca(sizeof(GroupNumRemap) * (env->num_mem + 1));
   ^
In file included from regparse.h:33:0,
                 from regcomp.c:31:
regint.h:195:21: warning: incompatible implicit declaration of built-in function 'alloca' [enabled by default]
 #define xalloca     alloca
                     ^
regcomp.c:2020:26: note: in expansion of macro 'xalloca'
   map = (GroupNumRemap* )xalloca(sizeof(GroupNumRemap) * (env->num_mem + 1));
                          ^
```

comments.body:
`alloca` is declared in `malloc.h` on major Win32 compilers (VC, MinGW, BCC), but currently `regint.h` includes `malloc.h` only when BCC is used. Maybe, it's better to include `malloc.h` always on Win32.
Actually, it seems that VC doesn't need to include `malloc.h` when using `_alloca` (not `alloca`), because it's a built-in function.

issue.title: /(?i)\u0149\u0149/ =~ "\u0149\u0149" doesn't match
issue.body:
How to reproduce:

```
$ LD_LIBRARY_PATH=.libs python

>>> from testpy import *
>>> set_encoding('UTF-8')
>>> set_output_encoding('UTF-8')
>>> x2(u"(?i)\u0149\u0149", u"\u0149\u0149", 0, 2)
FAIL: /(?i)ŉŉ/ 'ŉŉ'
```

It seems that Oniguruma 5.9.5 also has this bug.

comments.body:
`\u0149` is casefolded into `\u02bc` + `n`, then it is compiled into `exactn-ic:\xca\xbc` + `exact1-ic:n`.
One character is divided into two opcodes, so it couldn't match to a character `\u0149`.

Hmm, some tests failed.

> 3115 FAIL: /(?i)ΐ/ 'ΐ'

> 3459 search fail (ISO-8859-2)
> 3515 search fail (UTF-16BE)

> 3537 search fail (UTF-16BE)
> 3538 search fail (UTF-16BE)

Rebased and forcedly pushed.


issue.title: [[:punct:]] and \p{Punct}
issue.body:
Perl's document ([perlrecharclass](http://perldoc.perl.org/perlrecharclass.html#POSIX-Character-Classes)) says that:

> `\p{PosixPunct}` and `[[:punct:]]` in the ASCII range match all non-controls, non-alphanumeric, non-space characters: `[-!"#$%&'()*+,./:;<=>?@[\\\]^_`{|}~]`
> 
> The similarly named property, `\p{Punct}` , matches a somewhat different set in the ASCII range, namely `[-!"#%&'()*,./:;?@[\\\]_{}]`. That is, it is missing the nine characters `[$+<=>^`|~]`.

In current Onigmo, `[[:punct:]]` and `\p{Punct}` is the same in the ASCII range and they depend on the encoding.
If the encoding is Unicode encoding, `[[:punct:]]` and `\p{Punct}` don't match the nine characters.
If the encoding is not Unicode encoding, `[[:punct:]]` and `\p{Punct}` match the nine characters.

Is it OK?

comments.body:
I think this is wrong; both Unicode and non-Unicode should match the nine characters.

http://search.cpan.org/~shay/perl-5.20.2/pod/perlreref.pod

I believe the difference should actually be that under Unicode enoding, `[[:punct:]]` should additionally match non-ASCII punctuation. The "symbols" (`$+<=>^`|~`) should always be matched.

I have decided to change the behavior of `[[:punct:]]` on Unicode encodings, and already committed into `devel-6.0` branch.
Now `[[:punct:]]` matches the nine characters ```$+<=>^`|~``` on all encodings.
New property `\p{XPosixPunct}` can be used on Unicode encodings. This is the same as `(?u)[[:punct:]]`.
However `\p{Punct}` still works differently on Unicode encodings and non-Unicode encodings. It matches the nine characters on non-Unicode encodings, and doesn't match on Unicode encodings.
Closing.
Related: https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12577

timeline.body:

issue.title: Whitespace in /[...]/x
issue.body:
http://www.kt.rim.or.jp/~kbk/zakkicho/14/zakkicho1408b.html#D20140820-3
See: [[ruby-list:49923] whitespace in /[...]/x](http://blade.nagaokaut.ac.jp/cgi-bin/scat.rb/ruby/ruby-list/49923)

> 正規表現を x オプションで記述すると、空白を無視するとのことですが、
> 文字クラス内に記述した空白は無視されないようです。
> これは仕様でしょうか？

Currently, Onigmo doesn't ignore whitespace in a char class even if `ONIG_OPTION_EXTEND` option is specified.

Perl ignores it.
http://perldoc.perl.org/perlre.html#/x

Python doesn't ignore it.
https://docs.python.org/3.3/library/re.html#re.X

Is it better to add an option?

comments.body: Related: https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12477

> Perl ignores it.

Was this wrong?
Perl 5.24.0's document says: "... ignore most whitespace that is neither backslashed nor within a bracketed character class."

`/[ ]/x` matches to a space:

```
> perl -e "if (' ' =~ /[ ]/x){ print '<', $&, '>';}"
< >
```

issue.title: Support "true" extended grapheme cluster
issue.body:
Currently `\X` is defined as `(?>\P{M}\p{M}*)`. This definition is the same as [Perl 5.10](http://perldoc.perl.org/5.10.1/perlrebackslash.html#Misc). However the definition was changed as of [Perl 5.12](http://perldoc.perl.org/5.12.4/perlrebackslash.html#Misc).

See pp.15-18 of [this slide](https://speakerdeck.com/patch/unicode-regular-expression-engines). The slide says Onigmo supports legacy grapheme clusters.

See also: [UAX #29: Unicode Text Segmentation](http://unicode.org/reports/tr29/)

comments.body: Related: [/\X/ (extended grapheme cluster) can't pass unicode.org's GraphemeBreakTest](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12831)
Fixed.

issue.title: Remove `AS::Multibyte`'s unicode table

repository.name: rails
repository.description: Ruby on Rails

issue.body:
### Summary

@amatsuda tells us `AS::Multibyte` has big Unicode table and ruby may have similar feature (https://speakerdeck.com/a_matsuda/3x-rails?slide=156).

So I investigated and noticed that we can remove the table if we accept following changes.
- Supported Unicode version will depend on Ruby
  - Ruby 2.2 supports Unicode 7.0.0
  - Ruby 2.3 supports Unicode 8.0.0
  - Ruby 2.4 supports Unicode 9.0.0
- Unicode case mappings doesn't work until Ruby 2.4
- ~~Grapheme doesn't work perfect~~ Ruby 2.4 works perfect! https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12831

If we merge this PR, we'll have following benefits:
- Reduce memory usage(about 1M)
- Reduce repo/gem size(about 1M)
- Reduce code lines(about 400 lines)

I'll show you the way I tried to remove the table and why the changes will cause.

---

`AS::Multibyte::Unicode`'s features are divided into 4 main groups.
1. normalize
   -   [normalize](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v5.0.0.1/activesupport/lib/active_support/multibyte/unicode.rb#L285)
   -   [compose](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v5.0.0.1/activesupport/lib/active_support/multibyte/unicode.rb#L180)
   -   [decompose](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v5.0.0.1/activesupport/lib/active_support/multibyte/unicode.rb#L159)
   -   [reorder_characters](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v5.0.0.1/activesupport/lib/active_support/multibyte/unicode.rb#L143) (this is public method but probably for compose/decompose only)
2. case mapping
   -   [upcase](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v5.0.0.1/activesupport/lib/active_support/multibyte/unicode.rb#L307)
   -   [downcase](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v5.0.0.1/activesupport/lib/active_support/multibyte/unicode.rb#L303)
   -   [swapcase](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v5.0.0.1/activesupport/lib/active_support/multibyte/unicode.rb#L311)
3. pack/unpack grapheme
   - [pack_graphemes](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v5.0.0.1/activesupport/lib/active_support/multibyte/unicode.rb#L138)
   - [unpack_graphemes](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v5.0.0.1/activesupport/lib/active_support/multibyte/unicode.rb#L80)
4. tidy bytes
   - [tidy_bytes](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v5.0.0.1/activesupport/lib/active_support/multibyte/unicode.rb#L245)

1 ~ 3 use unicode database.
So let remove them.
#### normalize

Since 2.2, Ruby has `String#unicode_normalize`.

https://www.ruby-lang.org/en/news/2014/12/25/ruby-2-2-0-released/
https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/10084

[It has similar option](https://ruby-doc.org/stdlib-2.2.5/libdoc/unicode_normalize/rdoc/String.html#method-i-unicode_normalize) so it seems that we can simply replace it.
(I tried https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/26403)
But Ruby 2.2 supports Unicode 7.0.0 and Ruby 2.3 supports 8.0.0.
`AS::Multibyte::Unicode` has its own `UNICODE_VERSION` but now it depends on Ruby's version.
#### case mappings

[Ruby 2.4 supports Unicode case mappings](https://www.ruby-lang.org/en/news/2016/09/08/ruby-2-4-0-preview2-released/).
But Ruby 2.2 and 2.3 don't.
#### pack/unpack grapheme

Since 2.0, [Ruby changed its regexp engine](https://www.ruby-lang.org/en/news/2013/02/24/ruby-2-0-0-p0-is-released/).
So we can split grapheme with `/X/`.
(ex. `"\u304B\u3099\u304C\u3099\u304E\u3099".scan(/\X/)`)

~~But [it's grapheme cluster is not "true"](https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/issues/46).~~
~~So some tests will fail.~~
@nurse fixed on Ruby 2.4!
https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12831

#### Memory

Unicode database consume 1.5 M memory.

``` rb
require 'active_support/core_ext/string/multibyte'
require 'objspace'

# load unicode database
''.mb_chars.upcase

db = ActiveSupport::Multibyte::Unicode.send(:database)
db_memsize = db.instance_variables.map do |ivar|
  ObjectSpace.memsize_of(db.instance_variable_get(ivar))
end.inject(:+)

puts "db_memsize: #{db_memsize} Bytes"
#=> db_memsize: 1501184 Bytes
```

Ruby's Unicode database is smaller than `AS::Multibyte::Unicode::UnicodeDatabase`

``` rb
require 'objspace'

# load unicode database
''.unicode_normalize

db_memsize = UnicodeNormalize.constants.map do |const|
  ObjectSpace.memsize_of(UnicodeNormalize.const_get(const))
end.inject(:+)

puts "db_memsize: #{db_memsize} Bytes"
#=> db_memsize: 404558 Bytes
```

timeline.body: Related: [/\X/ (extended grapheme cluster) can't pass unicode.org's GraphemeBreakTest](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12831)
Fixed.

issue.title: Irregal capture after recursive match
issue.body:
Thank you very much for maintaining the excellent library.

I found the latest version of Onigmo suffers from the following incorrect behavior when used with a recursive expression.

`/\(((?:[^(]|\g<0>)*)\)/`  matches  `"(abc)(abc)"` => OK :green_heart:
`matches[0] == (0, 5)` corresponding to `"(abc)"` => OK :green_heart:
`matches[1] == (6, 4)` corresponding to _a string with negative length_ => NG :broken_heart:

`/\(((?:[^()]|\g<0>)*)\)/`  matches  `"((abc)(abc))"` => OK :green_heart:
`matches[0] == (0, 12)` corresponding to `"((abc)(abc))"` => OK :green_heart:
`matches[1] == (7, 11)` corresponding to `"abc)"` => NG :broken_heart:

It seems that `matches[].rm_so` refers to the _last capture_ while `matches[].rm_eo` refers to to the _top level capture_. I believe the users will be happier if both of them refers to the top level capture. When tested in ruby, the former example returns an invalid string for $2 that causes ArgumentError when given to a function as described at [ruby/正規表現](http://dora.bk.tsukuba.ac.jp/~takeuchi/index.php?%A5%D7%A5%ED%A5%B0%A5%E9%A5%DF%A5%F3%A5%B0%2Fruby%2F%C0%B5%B5%AC%C9%BD%B8%BD#q2562085).

comments.body:
Sorry for the very late response.
I think this is a bug of oniguruma/onigmo, but it seems difficult to fix.

I'm trying to investigate this, but I haven't found the cause yet.
Debug log: https://gist.github.com/k-takata/833f4ef7c4f94428e8de938103e97d5f

The first one has been fixed in the `devel-6.0` branch.
The second one is still under investigation.

I think I understand what happens with the second example.

Capturing happens three times: 

1. `(abc)(abc)`: position 1 to 11, nest level 1
2. the first `abc`: position 2 to 5, nest level 2
3. the second `abc`: position 7 to 10, nest level 2

Matching sequence is the following:

1. Start of the 1st one captures position 1.
2. Start of the 2nd one captures position 2.
3. End of the 2nd one captures position 5.
4. Start of the 3rd one captures position 7.
5. End of the 3rd one captures position 10.
6. End of the 1st one captures position 11.

Finally, the last captured position of start and end will be returned.
So the start of `\1` becomes 7 (No.4) and the end of `\1` becomes 11 (No.6).
The nest level is not considered here.

> I believe the users will be happier if both of them refers to the top level capture.

I'm not sure this can be easily implemented. Also not sure this doesn't break existing behavior for non-nested capturing.
Need more investigation...

Thank you very much for your detailed investigation.

I imagine that if we push the start and end positions on the nest-level stack and pop them from it at the nest-level switching, the problem will be solved. Note that it does not affect non-nested capturing.

I'm afraid the first one should have been fixed in the same manner.

I do not know how difficult to implement it though...
I think this is fixed by the latest commit.

Thank you very much for the fix.

I wonder if the commit dd4638c was really needed independently from 7591b3c.
Doesn't 7591b3c fix the first example?

I can't follow the logic precisely but, I imagine the two failed tests originate from a same origin.

dd4638c9235381aa2363484a869628d71e8eea68 is needed to store the start/end position of each capturing to a stack.
Without this, the position will be overwritten by the latest one.

I thought even if it is overwritten, it is recovered at level switching but it seems my imagination.
Sorry for bothering and thank you again for your labor.

I found a better solution for this. Even without my fixes, [a pattern](https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/blob/0979a9f8d7d2b79769a397722519596a77f6471a/sample/listcap.c#L111) in `sample/listcap.c` captured as expected with recursive match. This meant that Onigmo had a mechanism to handle nested captures. 1. `\g

(?@

\(\g\)){0}(?@(?:\g

)*|){0}` 2. `\(((?:[^(]|\g<0>)*)\)` Difference between 1 and 2 is whether captured groups are directly called or not. In 1, both `

` and `` are directly referenced by `\g

` and `\g`. In 2, the whole pattern is referenced by `\g<0>` but `\1` is not referenced. It is indirectly called via `\g<0>`. Now, with the commit 4bd79e2d0039a44d3f736ede00baf81820a290fc, captured groups which are called indirectly are also handled as if they are called directly. BTW, I'm not sure both `IN_CALL` and `IN_RECCALL` in the commit are really needed.

issue.title: Fix illegal capture after recursive call

repository.name: oniguruma
repository.description: regular expression library

issue.body:
After matching `/(\(((?:[^(]|\g<1>)*)\))/ =~ "(abc)(abc)"`,
`\2` captures wrong position.
A capture group inside another capture group should be also handled as
if it is called, when the outer group is called.

(I'm not sure both `IN_CALL` and `IN_RECCALL` are needed or not.)

Originally reported at k-takata/Onigmo#48 .

issue.title: Use Direct Threaded Code
issue.body:
Direct threaded code can make a VM faster, but GCC extension is needed to implement it. (Of cause VC doesn't support the extension.)
However, there is a way to support both GCC-compatible and non-GCC-compatible compiler in one code base.
E.g. [picrin](https://github.com/picrin-scheme/picrin) supports both direct threaded code and normal swich-case based code. (https://github.com/picrin-scheme/picrin/blob/master/extlib/benz/vm.c#L583)

See also: [Rubyist Magazine - YARV Maniacs 【第 3 回】 命令ディスパッチの高速化](http://magazine.rubyist.net/?0008-YarvManiacs)

comments.body:
Implemented in #52 by @KeenS. Thank you.
Closing.

timeline.body:
Implemented in #52 by @KeenS. Thank you.
Closing.

issue.title: Support Direct Threaded VM

repository.name: Onigmo
repository.description: Onigmo is a regular expressions library forked from Oniguruma.

issue.body:
## Motivations:
- Onigumo implements token threaded VM but didn't implement direct threaded code yet.
- https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/issues/51

## Changes:
- Add a pointer field to each bytecode to hold label pointer.
- Jump to next op without label table lookup

## Results:
- Increase Bytecode memory usage (8 *n bytes)
- Faster pattern match (except `\b\w+nn\b`) at least at M1 mac (will check perf at other platform e.g. x86 later)

Here are benchmark scores. Benchmark suite is derived form http://sljit.sourceforge.net/regex_perf.html.
```
$ cc --version
Apple clang version 12.0.5 (clang-1205.0.22.11)
Target: arm64-apple-darwin20.6.0
Thread model: posix
InstalledDir: /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Toolchains/XcodeDefault.xctoolchain/usr/bin
```

|  Pattern  |  Current  | Proposal |
| ---- | ---- | ---- |
| Twain | 15 ms | 15 ms|
| (?i)Twain | 60 ms | 18 ms|
| [a-z]shing| 14 ms |13 ms|
| Huck[a-zA-Z]+\|Saw[a-zA-Z]+| 20 ms | 16 ms|
| \b\w+nn\b| 394 ms | 414 ms|
| [a-q][^u-z]{13}x| 20 ms | 7 ms|
| Tom\|Sawyer\|Huckleberry\|Finn| 25 ms | 19 ms|
| (?i)Tom\|Sawyer\|Huckleberry\|Finn| 236 ms | 179 ms|
| .{0,2}(Tom\|Sawyer\|Huckleberry\|Finn)| 48 ms | 38 ms|
| .{2,4}(Tom\|Sawyer\|Huckleberry\|Finn)| 46 ms | 44 ms|
| Tom.{10,25}river\|river.{10,25}Tom| 42 ms | 41 ms|
| [a-zA-Z]+ing| 509 ms | 410 ms|
| \s[a-zA-Z]{0,12}ing\s| 48 ms | 44 ms|
| ([A-Za-z]awyer\|[A-Za-z]inn)\s| 101 ms | 99 ms|
| ["'][^"']{0,30}[?!\.]["']| 44 ms | 39 ms|

issue.title: Regexp matching with \p{Upper} and \p{Lower} for EUC-JP doesn’t work.
issue.body:
U+FF21 (Ａ, FULLWIDTH LATIN CAPITAL LETTER A) and U+00c0 (À, LATIN CAPITAL LETTER A WITH GRAVE) is `Uppercase_Letter` so it should match and return 0 in following cases but this returns 1.

``` Ruby
ruby -e 'puts "\uFF21A".encode("EUC-JP") =~ Regexp.compile("\\\p{Upper}".encode("EUC-JP”))' # => 1
ruby -e 'puts "\u00C0A".encode("EUC-JP") =~ Regexp.compile("\\\p{Upper}".encode("EUC-JP"))' # => 1
```

This also happens in lower case matching.

``` Ruby
ruby -e 'puts "\uFF41a".encode("EUC-JP") =~ Regexp.compile("\\\p{Lower}".encode("EUC-JP"))' ＃=> 1
```

In Unicode encoding it works as follows.

``` Ruby
ruby -e 'puts "\uFF21A" =~ Regexp.compile("\\\p{Upper}")'  # => 0
```

Looks like EUC-JP `\p{Upper}` and `\p{Lower}` regex is limited to ASCII characters.

comments.body:
https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11859#change-59185

> Ruby doesn't have case tables for non Unicode encodings.
> 
> And EUC-JP is legacy encoding, I don't think such encoding should be extended.

I have the same opinion. Closing.

timeline.body:
https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11859#change-59185

> Ruby doesn't have case tables for non Unicode encodings.
> 
> And EUC-JP is legacy encoding, I don't think such encoding should be extended.

I have the same opinion. Closing.

issue.title: Thread safety of onig_search and onig_match.
issue.body:
Forgive me if I'm working from incorrect assumptions as I've just begun integrating Onigmo into one of my projects. My understanding is that these functions are intended to be thread-safe.

Looking at the implementation of these `onig_search` and `onig_match`, I notice the following code attempting some synchronization at the start:

``` C
#if defined(USE_RECOMPILE_API) && defined(USE_MULTI_THREAD_SYSTEM)
start:
THREAD_ATOMIC_START;
...
```

This seems to be part of a (perhaps defunct?) feature, hidden behind `USE_RECOMPILE_API` that isn't set anywhere, that would recompile the regular expression from within `onig_search` and `onig_match`, something that's obviously not thread safe and needs to be protected (although a global lock would kill throughput).

Given that there appears to be no other synchronization in use other than this (dead?) code, I thought I would try changing the functions to take `const regex_t*` instead of `regex_t*` to at least signal thread safety with respect to the regular expression struct.

[Here is a comparison of a commit that adds const where needed](https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/compare/master...peterhuene:thread-safety).

Well, that wasn't that bad of a change, but unfortunately it won't build because [set_bm_backward_skip is used to modify the int_map_backward field of regex_t](https://github.com/peterhuene/Onigmo/blob/51a3b9d1021a00b35705ff4371a64feae3150631/regexec.c#L3834).  At first glance, this does not appear to be a thread safe mutation of `regex_t` state.

Is that the case or is this not a problem?

comments.body:
Sorry for the very late response.
Now I'm thinking that removing all `THREAD_*` macro and making Onigmo thread-safe as Oniguruma 6.0 did.

Now the all `THREAD_*` macros are removed in `devel-6.0` branch.
`set_bm_backward_skip()` is also disabled now.
Thanks!

Now the all `THREAD_*` macros are removed in `devel-6.0` branch.

Thanks!

issue.title: Plan for Onigmo 6.0
issue.body:
About one year ago [Oniguruma](https://github.com/kkos/oniguruma) restarted on GitHub, and Oniguruma 6.0 was released about five months ago. Unfortunately new syntax I implemented in Onigmo like `\K`, `\X` and etc. were not merged in Oniguruma, and I don't think K.Kosako is going to merge them.
I think Ongimo and Oniguruma are now diverged and won't be merged again.

Currently Onigmo and Oniguruma cannot be installed in the same system, because Onigmo still uses the same header/library filenames. They should be changed now.

I'm planing that:
- Rename the header and library filenames: `onigmo.h`, `libonigmo.so`, `onigmo.dll`, etc.
- Import the latest Ruby's source code. This includes support for Unicode 9.0 and improvement of case folding. (Already merged into the `ruby-2.x` branch.)
- Merge the `ruby-2.x` branch into `master`. Ruby specific codes should be surrounded by `#ifdef RUBY`.
- Change some APIs. (Some of them come from the side effect of merging the `ruby-2.x` branch.)
  - Encoding structs and syntax structs will become const.
  - Change some encoding name. E.g. `ONIG_ENCODING_UTF8` -> `ONIG_ENCODING_UTF_8`. However the old names still can be used, because I will define aliases for backward compatibility. (But the old structure names like `OnigEncodingUTF8` will not be used. They are not considered as a part of public API.)
  - (Import Oniguruma 6.x's new APIs?)
    - `onig_scan`: Maybe useful and easy to import.
    - `onig_unicode_define_user_property`: Not sure how this is useful.
    - `onig_initialize`: Not sure why this is needed. Related to thread safe?
- (Make Onigmo thread safe and remove all `THREAD_*` macros like Oniguruma did?)
- Merge bug fixes done in Oniguruma 6.x. Need to check if they are already fixed in Onigmo.

I wonder why this API is limited to Unicode encodings only.

Onigmo 6.0.0 has been released: https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/releases/tag/Onigmo-6.0.0
Closing.

Currently Onigmo cannot be build both for x86 and x64 in the same source directory at the same time.
It's better to use separate build directories. E.g. `build_x86` and `build_x64`.

issue.title: Deeply nested capture groups cause stack overflow
issue.body:
How to reproduce:

``` python
from testpy import *
# import onigmo
# set_encoding("UTF-8")
# set_output_encoding()
x2("(" * 32767 + "a" + ")" * 32767, "a", 0, 1)
```

Related: ~~#18~~ #24

This also occurs on Oniguruma 6.1.1.
Cc: @kkos

issue.title: Deeply nested capture groups cause stack overflow

repository.name: oniguruma
repository.description: regular expression library

issue.body:
Oniguruma's parser uses recursion, so it causes stack overflow when parsing
deeply nested capture groups. E.g.:

  x2("(" * 32767 + "a" + ")" * 32767, "a", 0, 1)

This patch sets a limit for this.
The default value is defined in regint.h:
* DEFAULT_PARSE_DEPTH_LIMIT (Currently 4096)

Also add two APIs to support this:
* onig_get_parse_depth_limit
* onig_set_parse_depth_limit

Ported from k-takata/Onigmo#68 .

issue.title: Backward search with .*
issue.body:
https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/blob/2cb0bec3e7ffe05c5eaad5d3f4b49e06dac48161/testpy.py#L1419-L1422

`/.*[a-z]bc/` and `/.+[a-z]bc/` both match to 0-6 (`abcabc`),
but `/.{1,3}[a-z]bc/` matches to 2-6 (`cabc`).

Shouldn't be as follows?
`/.*[a-z]bc/`: 3-6
`/.+[a-z]bc/`: 2-6
`/.{1,3}[a-z]bc/`: 2-6

comments.body: I need to check with oniguruma.

Fixed.

issue.title: Support Perl's \h and \v
issue.body:
The following two should be supported on Perl syntax:

`\h`: horizontal white space
`\v`: vertical white space

They conflict with Ruby syntax, so they will not be supported on Ruby syntax.

issue.body: Remove `HAVE_STDARG_PROTOTYPES`, `HAVE_PROTOTYPES` and drop support for very old compilers which don't support `stdarg.h`.

issue.title: Named backrefs in conditional expressions behave differently
issue.body:
Named backrefs in conditional expressions (`(?(<name>)yes|no)`) behave differently from normal named backrefs (`\k<name>`) in Ruby syntax.
`\k<name>` checks the last group with the name, if not matched then the previous one, and so on, until there is a match. (https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/blob/b33408146c093f1a35bb8b85e2237329d749e8ef/doc/RE#L321-L323)
However `(?(<name>)yes|no)` only checks the left most group with the name. This behavior of the conditional expressions is the same as Perl, but inconsistent for Ruby.
The same strategy with `\k<name>` should be used for Ruby syntax.

Related: #74

issue.title: Named backrefs behave differently in Perl syntax

repository.name: Onigmo
repository.description: Onigmo is a regular expressions library forked from Oniguruma.

issue.body:
Named backrefs (`\k<name>`, `\g{name}`) refer only the left most group with the name in Perl.
However they behave differently in Onigmo with Perl syntax. (https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/blob/b33408146c093f1a35bb8b85e2237329d749e8ef/doc/RE#L321-L323)
They should refer only the left most group in Perl syntax.

Related: #73

issue.title: Captured strings of (.)(\g<1>) are same

repository.name: Onigmo
repository.description: Onigmo is a regular expressions library forked from Oniguruma.

issue.body:
Ruby code:

```rb
p /(.)(\g<1>)/.match("AB")
# => #<MatchData "AB" 1:"B" 2:"B">
```

I expected the following result:

```rb
# => #<MatchData "AB" 1:"A" 2:"B">
```

issue.title: Remove ONIG_OPTION_POSIX_REGION
issue.body:
The option [`ONIG_OPTION_POSIX_REGION`](https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/blob/e7a614b0f55a3176d94cc96b706a74f93bf59ee0/doc/API#L289) is currently used for implementing a POSIX compatible API `regexec()`. However this causes [duplication of code](https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/blob/f4b06ccee342b0c51aaff94822565245f0e4138f/regexec.c#L1710-L1751) in `regexec.c`.
I don't think `regexec.c` should handle `regmatch_t` directly. It should be handled inside `regposix.c`.

comments.body: Removed.

issue.title: Implement Absent Operator
issue.body:
Slide and paper by Akira Tanaka (@akr) (both Japanese):

* [正規表現における非包含オペレータの提案](https://staff.aist.go.jp/tanaka-akira/pub/prosym49-akr-presen.pdf)
* [Absent Operator for Regular Expression](https://staff.aist.go.jp/tanaka-akira/pub/prosym49-akr-paper.pdf)

TODO:

* Syntax:
  Maybe the form of `(?...)` should be used. For example `(?~...)`?
* Implementation:
  Is it easy?

comments.body:
Akira's paper says that look-ahead assertion doesn't have theoretical backgrounds. However @sinya8282 says that look-ahead assertion is a regular expression (in context of formal language theory), and it can be proved by using boolean automaton.
Then absent operator can be a syntax sugar of `(?:(?!expr)(?m:.))*`?

It seems that `(?~expr)` is different from `(?:(?!expr).)*`.
`\A(?~abc)c` should match `abc` (because `(?~abc)` matches `ab`), but `\A(?:(?!abc).)*c` doesn't match.

https://twitter.com/nalsh/status/809375869626150912

`topic/absent-operator` branch was merged into the master branch.
Maybe more tests are needed, but closing for now.

> However @sinya8282 says that look-ahead assertion is a regular expression

This is discussed in a paper by Akimasa MORIHATA:

* [Translation of Regular Expression with Lookahead into Finite State Automaton](https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jssst/29/1/29_1_1_147/_article/) (PDF in Japanese)

Related?
[Feature #5588: add negation flag (v) to Regexp - Ruby trunk - Ruby Issue Tracking System](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/5588 "Feature #5588: add negation flag (v) to Regexp - Ruby trunk - Ruby Issue Tracking System")

issue.title: Write specs for new Ruby 2.4 features and changes

repository.name: spec
repository.description: The Ruby Spec Suite aka ruby/spec

issue.body:
ruby/spec already contains some specs for 2.4, but we should aim to cover all new features and important changes.
This will improve the test coverage of these features, allow other Ruby implementations to implement these faster with more confidence and document clearly the new behavior.

The new specs should be within a version guard block:
```ruby
ruby_version_is "2.4" do
  # New specs
end
```

From https://github.com/ruby/ruby/blob/ruby_2_4/NEWS:
Only relevant items are kept for brevity.

# NEWS for Ruby 2.4

This document is a list of user visible feature changes made between releases except for bug fixes.

## Changes since the 2.3.0 release

### Language changes

- [x] #504 Multiple assignment in conditional expression is now allowed.  [Feature #10617](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/10617)

- [x] #509 Rescue modifier now applicable to method arguments.  [Feature #12686](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12686)

- [x] #530 Toplevel return is now allowed.  [Feature #4840](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/4840)

### Core classes updates (outstanding ones only)

* Array

  - [x] #375 Array#concat [Feature #12333](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12333)
    Now takes multiple arguments.

  - [x] f07c3de42de7ccaf021cff62af520d11db62966e 630ed7f2bfcd68ccd8d53651fb8344fd90c4a510 Array#max and Array#min.  [Feature #12172](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12172)
    This may cause a tiny incompatibility: if you redefine
    Enumerable#max and call max to an Array, your redefinition will be
    now ignored.  You should also redefine Array#max.

  - [x] #495 Array#pack [Feature #12754](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12754)
    Now takes optional argument `buffer:' to reuse already allocated buffer.

  - [x] #492 Array#sum (can share with 7f2961d95aeb06719bd80399092e15af37a853d4) [Feature #12217](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12217)
    This is different from Enumerable#sum in that Array#sum doesn't depend on
    the definition of each method.

* Comparable

  - [x] 6baf83f4b00fcbbabcc87405889d352f5651eb6f Comparable#clamp.  [Feature #10594](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/10594)

* Dir

  - [x] #481 #482 Dir.empty?.  [Feature #10121](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/10121)

* Enumerable

  - [x] e00328a1fefd56dcc82421e689d971de3926f7bd Enumerable#chunk called without a block now return an Enumerator    [Feature #2172](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/2172)
  - [x] #446 Enumerable#sum  [Feature #12217](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12217)
  - [x] #447 Enumerable#uniq  [Feature #11090](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11090)

* Enumerator::Lazy

  - [x] #506 Enumerator::Lazy#chunk_while  [GH-1186](https://github.com/ruby/ruby/pull/1186)
  - [x] #448 Enumerator::Lazy#uniq  [Feature #11090](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11090)

* File

  - [x] #476 File.empty?.  [Feature #9969](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/9969)

* Float

  - [x] #475  Float#ceil, Float#floor, and Float#truncate now take an optional
    digits, as well as Float#round.  [Feature #12245](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12245)

  - [x] #477 Float#round now takes an optional keyword argument, half option, and
    the default behavior is round-up.  [Bug #12548](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12548) [Bug #12958](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12958)
    half option can be one of :even, :up, and :down.  [Feature #12953](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12953)

* Hash

  - [x] #376 Hash#compact and Hash#compact!  [Feature #11818](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11818)
  - [x] #377 Hash#transform_values and Hash#transform_values!  [Feature #12512](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12512)

* Integer

  - [x] #483 Integer#ceil, Integer#floor, and Integer#truncate now take an optional
    digits, as well as Integer#round.  [Feature #12245](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12245)

  - [x] #485 Integer#digits for extracting columns of place-value notation [Feature #12447](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12447)

  - [x] #478 Integer#round now takes an optional keyword argument, half option, and the
    default behavior is round-up now.  [Bug #12548](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12548) [Bug #12958](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12958)
    half option can be one of :even, :up, and :down.  [Feature #12953](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12953)

* IO

  - [x] #503 IO#gets, IO#readline, IO#each_line, IO#readlines, IO.foreach now takes
    an optional keyword argument, chomp flag.  [Feature #12553](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12553)

* Kernel

  - [x] #451 Kernel#clone now takes an optional keyword argument, freeze flag.  [Feature #12300](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12300)

* MatchData

  - [x] #449 MatchData#named_captures [Feature #11999](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11999)
  - [x] #450 MatchData#values_at supports named captures [Feature #9179](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/9179)

* Module

  - Module#refine accepts a module as the argument now. [Feature #12534](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12534)
  - Module.used_modules [Feature #7418](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/7418)

* Numeric

  - [x] #487 Numeric#finite?, Numeric#infinite? [Feature #12039](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12039)

* Process

  - [x] Support CLOCK_MONOTONIC_RAW_APPROX, CLOCK_UPTIME_RAW, and
    CLOCK_UPTIME_RAW_APPROX which are introduced by macOS 10.12.

* Rational

  - [x] #493 Rational#round now takes an optional keyword argument, half option, and
    the default behavior is round-up now.  [Bug #12548](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12548) [Bug #12958](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12958)
    half option can be one of :even, :up, and :down.  [Feature #12953](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12953)

* Regexp

  - [x] #511 meta character \X matches Unicode 9.0 characters with some workarounds
    for UTR #51 Unicode Emoji, Version 4.0 emoji zwj sequences.

  - [x] #379 Regexp#match? [Feature #8110](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/8110)
    This returns bool and doesn't save backref.

  * Update Onigmo 6.1.1.
    - [x] #532 Support absent operator https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/issues/82

* Regexp/String:
  - [x] Updated Unicode version from 8.0.0 to 9.0.0 [Feature #12513](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12513)

* String

  - [x] #474 String#casecmp? [Feature #12786](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12786)

  - [x] #375 String#concat, String#prepend [Feature #12333](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12333)
    Now takes multiple arguments.

  - [x] #498 String#each_line, String#lines now takes an optional keyword argument,
    chomp flag.  [Feature #12553](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12553)

  - [x] #379 String#match? [Feature #12898](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12898)

  - [x] #488 String#unpack1 [Feature #12752](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12752)

  - [x] #501 9c24b006b5e21d2596933f3878c8e2baee72c774 String#upcase, String#downcase, String#capitalize, String#swapcase and
    their bang variants work for all of Unicode, and are no longer limited
    to ASCII. Supported encodings are UTF-8, UTF-16BE/LE, UTF-32BE/LE, and
    ISO-8859-1~16. Variations are available with options. See the documentation
    of String#downcase for details. [Feature #10085](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/10085)

  - [x] #499 String.new(capacity: size) [Feature #12024](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12024)

* StringIO

  - [x] #505 StringIO#gets, StringIO#readline, StringIO#each_line, StringIO#readlines now takes
    an optional keyword argument, chomp flag.  [Feature #12553](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12553)

* Symbol

  - [x] #480 Symbol#casecmp? [Feature #12786](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12786)

  - [x] 51d46b1c8b672fd679287bb3964295b3a64cc7aa 7604cbcd03c6c5bde3e8f6b11351f05f52d628d0 Symbol#match now returns MatchData.  [Bug #11991](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11991)
repo
  - [x] #379 Symbol#match? [Feature #12898](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12898)

  - [x] #502 Symbol#upcase, Symbol#downcase, Symbol#capitalize, and Symbol#swapcase now
    work for all of Unicode. See the documentation of String#downcase
    for details. [Feature #10085](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/10085)

* Thread

  - [x] #517 Thread#report_on_exception and Thread.report_on_exception    [Feature #6647](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/6647)

* TracePoint

  - [x] #508 TracePoint#callee_id [Feature #12747](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12747)

* Warning

  - [x] #512 New module named Warning is introduced.  By default it has only
    one singleton method, named warn.  This makes it possible for
    3rd-party libraries to control the way warnings are handled.    [Feature #12299](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12299)

### Stdlib updates (outstanding ones only)

* CGI

  - [x] #486 Don't allow , as a separator [Bug #12791](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12791)

* CSV

  - [x] #524 Add a liberal_parsing option. [Feature #11839](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11839)

* IPAddr

  - [x] #519 IPAddr#== and IPAddr#<=> no longer raise an exception if coercion fails.    [Bug #12799](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12799)

* IRB

  - [x] Binding#irb: Start a REPL session like `binding.pry` at https://github.com/ruby/ruby/commit/493e48897421d176a8faf0f0820323d79ecdf94a.

* Logger

  - [x] #527 Allow specifying logger parameters in constructor such
    as level, progname, datetime_format, formatter. [Feature #12224](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12224)
  - [x] #528 Add shift_period_suffix option. [Feature #10772](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/10772)

* Net::HTTP

  - [x] #520 New method: Net::HTTP.post [Feature #12375](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12375)

* Net::FTP

  - [x] #540 Support hash style options for Net::FTP.new.
  - [x] #479 Add a new optional argument pathname to Net::FTP#status.
    Contributed by soleboxy. [GH-1478](https://github.com/ruby/ruby/pull/1478) [Feature #12965](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12965)

* optparse

  - [x] #523 Add an into option. [Feature #11191](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11191)

* pathname

  - [x] #484 New method: Pathname#empty? [Feature #12596](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12596)

* REXML

  - [x] #531 REXML::Element#[]: If String or Symbol is specified, attribute
    value is returned. Otherwise, Nth child is returned. This is
    backward compatible change.

* set

  - [x] #507 #510 New methods: Set#compare_by_identity and Set#compare_by_identity?.    [Feature #12210](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12210)

### Compatibility issues (excluding feature bug fixes)

- [x] #497 (need to add some specs to check Fixnum==Integer==Bignum and the #class of some values) Fixnum and Bignum are unified into Integer  [Feature #12005](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12005)
  Fixnum class and Bignum class is removed.
  Integer class is changed from abstract class to concrete class.
  For example, 0 is an instance of Integer: 0.class returns Integer.
  The constants Fixnum and Bignum is bound to Integer.
  So obj.kind_of?(Fixnum) works as obj.kind_of?(Integer).
  At C-level, Fixnum object and Bignum object should be distinguished by
  FIXNUM_P(obj) and RB_TYPE_P(obj, T_BIGNUM).
  RUBY_INTEGER_UNIFICATION can be used to detect this feature at C-level.
  0.class == Integer can be used to detect this feature at Ruby-level.
  The C-level constants, rb_cFixnum and rb_cBignum, are removed.
  They can cause compilation failure.

- [x] 9c24b006b5e21d2596933f3878c8e2baee72c774 String/Symbol#upcase/downcase/swapcase/capitalize(!) now work for all of
  Unicode, not only for ASCII. [Feature #10085](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/10085)
  No change is needed if the data is in ASCII anyway or if the limitation
  to ASCII was only tolerated while waiting for a more extensive implementation.
  A change (using the :ascii option) is needed in cases where Unicode data
  is processed, but the operation has to be limited to ASCII only.
  A good example of this are internationalized domain names.

- [x] bd885a6c02ccef31d2b49361e049c724cacfa024 TRUE / FALSE / NIL
  These constants are now obsoleted. [Feature #12574](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12574)
  Use true / false / nil resp. instead.

### Stdlib compatibility issues (excluding feature bug fixes)

* DateTime

  - [x] #490 DateTime#to_time now preserves timezone.  [Bug #12189](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12189)

* shellwords

  - [x] #525 Shellwords.shellwords (shellsplit) treats the backslash as escape
    character only when followed by one of the following characters:
    $ ` " \ <newline>    [Bug #10055](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/10055)

* Time

  - [x] #490 Time#to_time now preserves timezone.  [Bug #12271](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12271)

* Zlib

  - [x] Zlib.gzip and Zlib.gunzip [Feature #13020](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13020)

### C API updates

- [x] rb_gc_adjust_memory_usage() [Feature #12690](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12690)

### Implementation improvements

- Thread deadlock detection now shows their backtrace and dependency. [Feature #8214](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/8214)

### Not in the NEWS file

- [x] #472 38a6a1e4967c1873cb66aee65c87fcb9d758da04 `true`, `false`, `nil`, `Integer`, `Symbol`, etc no longer raise `TypeError` for `dup` and `clone`, but return `self`. [Feature #12979](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12979)

issue.title: Ruby 2.5 Support

repository.name: jruby
repository.description: JRuby, an implementation of Ruby on the JVM

issue.body:
This issue will track Ruby 2.5 support for JRuby. This will be released in JRuby 9.3.0.0 or JRuby 10.

As with previous releases, we will base our checklist on MRI's NEWS file: https://github.com/ruby/ruby/blob/trunk/NEWS
This bug will track all NEWS items new in Ruby 2.5. This list is based off https://github.com/ruby/ruby/blob/trunk/NEWS.

Only changes relevant to JRuby are listed here. MRI-specific internal changes and features are not included.

NOTE: Pull requests should be done against the `ruby-2.5` branch.

### Language changes

- [x] Top-level constant look-up is removed.  [Feature #11547](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11547)
- [x] rescue/else/ensure are allowed inside do/end blocks.  [Feature #12906](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12906)
- [ ] refinements take place in string interpolations.  [Feature #13812](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13812)

### Core classes updates (outstanding ones only)

#### Array

- [x]  `Array#append`  [Feature #12746](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12746)
- [x]  `Array#prepend`  [Feature #12746](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12746)

#### Data

- [x] Now deprecated [Feature #3072](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/3072)

#### Dir

- [x] `Dir.glob` provides new optional keyword argument, `:base`. [Feature #13056](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13056)
- [x] `Dir.children`  [Feature #11302](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11302)
- [x] `Dir.each_child`  [Feature #11302](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11302)

#### File

- [ ]  :newline option to `File.open` implies text mode now.  [Bug #13350](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13350)
- [x]  `File#path` now raises an IOError for files opened with `File::Constants::TMPFILE` option. [Feature #13568](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13568)
- [x]  Add `File.lutime`  [Feature #4052](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/4052)

#### Hash

- [x] `Hash#transform_keys`  [Feature #13583](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13583)
- [x] `Hash#transform_keys!`  [Feature #13583](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13583)
- [x] `Hash#slice`  [Feature #8499](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/8499)

#### IO

- [ ] `IO#pread`  [Feature #4532](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/4532)
- [ ] `IO#pwrite`  [Feature #4532](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/4532)
- [ ] `IO#copy_stream` tries copy offload with `copy_file_range(2)` [Feature #13867](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13867)
- [x] `IO#write` accepts multiple arguments  [Feature #9323](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/9323)

#### IOError

- [x] exception message "stream closed" is changed  [Bug #13405](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13405)

#### Integer

- [x] `Integer.sqrt`  [Feature #13219](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13219)
- [x] `Integer#step` does no longer rescue exceptions when given a step value which cannot be compared with `#>` to 0. [Feature #7688](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/7688)
- [x] `Integer#{round,floor,ceil,truncate}` now always return an Integer. [Bug #13420](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13420)
- [x] `Integer#pow` added

#### Kernel

- [x] `Kernel#yield_self`  [Feature #6721](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/6721)
- [x] `Kernel#pp` [Feature #14123](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/14123)

#### Module

- [x] `Module#attr`, `attr_accessor`, `attr_reader`, `attr_writer` are now public [Feature #14132]
- [x] `Module#define_method`, `alias_method`, `undef_method`, `remove_method` are now public [Feature #14133]

#### Numeric

- [x] Numerical comparison operators (`<` ,`<=`, `>=`, `>`) no longer rescue exceptions of `#coerce`. Return nil in `#coerce` if the coercion is impossible. [Feature #7688](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/7688)

#### Process

- [ ] Precision of `Process.times` is improved if `getrusage(2)` exists. [Feature #11952](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11952)

#### Range

- [x] `Range#initialize` no longer rescue exceptions when comparing begin and
    end with `#<=>` and raise a "bad value for range" ArgumentError
    but instead let the exception from the `#<=>` call go through.
    [Feature #7688](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/7688)

#### Regexp

- [x] Update to Onigmo 6.1.1.
- [ ] Support absent operator https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/issues/82

#### String

- [x] `String#-@` deduplicates unfrozen strings.  Already-frozen strings remain unchanged for compatibility.  [Feature #13077](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13077)
- [x] -"literal" (`String#-@`) optimized to return the same object (same as "literal".freeze in Ruby 2.1+) [Feature #13295](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13295)
- [x] `String#{casecmp,casecmp?}` now return nil for non-string arguments instead of raising a TypeError. [Bug #13312](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13312)

issue.title: Write specs for new Ruby 2.5 features and changes

repository.name: spec
repository.description: The Ruby Spec Suite aka ruby/spec

issue.body:
ruby/spec already contains many specs for 2.5, but we should aim to cover all new features and important changes.
This will improve the test coverage of these features (and maybe discover a few bugs along the way), allow other Ruby implementations to implement the changes faster with more confidence and document clearly the new behavior.

The new specs should be within a version guard block:
```ruby
ruby_version_is "2.5" do
  # New specs
end
```

From https://github.com/ruby/ruby/blob/trunk/NEWS.
Only relevant items are kept for brevity.

## NEWS for Ruby 2.5.0

## Changes since the 2.4.0 release

### Language changes

- [x] rescue/else/ensure are allowed inside do/end blocks.  [Feature #12906](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12906)
- [x] Top-level constant look-up is removed.  [Feature #11547](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11547)


- [x] refinements take place in string interpolations.  [Feature #13812](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13812)

### Core classes updates (outstanding ones only)

Array

- [x] Array#append  [Feature #12746](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12746)
- [x] Array#prepend  [Feature #12746](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12746)

Data

- [x] Is deprecated. It was a base class for C extensions, and it's not
  necessary to expose in Ruby level. [Feature #3072](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/3072)

Exception

- [x] Exception#full_message to retrieve a String expression of an exception,
  formatted in the same way in which Ruby prints out an uncaught exception.
  [Feature #14141](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/14141) [experimental]

Dir

- [x] Dir.children  [Feature #11302](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11302)
- [x] Dir.each_child  [Feature #11302](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11302)

Enumerable

- [x] Enumerable#{any?,all?,none?,one?} accept a pattern argument [Feature #11286](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11286)

File

- [x] File.open accepts :newline option to imply text mode.  [Bug #13350](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13350)
- [x] File#path raises an IOError for files opened with
  File::Constants::TMPFILE option. [Feature #13568](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13568)
- [x] File::Stat#{atime,mtime,ctime} support fractional second timestamps on
  Windows 8 and later  [Feature #13726](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13726)
- [x] File::Stat#ino and File.indentical? support ReFS 128bit ino on Windows 8.1
  and later  [Feature #13731](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13731)
- [x] File.lutime  [Feature #4052](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/4052)

Hash

- [x] Hash#transform_keys  [Feature #13583](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13583)

- [x] Hash#slice  [Feature #8499](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/8499)

IO

- [x] IO#pread  [Feature #4532](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/4532)
- [x] IO#pwrite  [Feature #4532](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/4532)
- [x] IO#copy_stream tries copy offload with copy_file_range(2) [Feature #13867](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13867)
- [x] IO#write accepts multiple arguments  [Feature #9323](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/9323)

IOError

- [x] IO#close might raise an error with message "stream closed",
  but it is refined to "stream closed in another thread". The new message
  is more clear for user.
  [Bug #13405](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13405)

Integer

- [x] Integer#step no longer hides errors from coerce method when
  given a step value which cannot be compared with #> to 0.
  [Feature #7688](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/7688)
- [x] Integer#{round,floor,ceil,truncate} always return an Integer.
  [Bug #13420](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13420)
- [x] #573 Integer#pow accepts modulo argument for calculating modular
  exponentiation.  [Feature #12508](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12508) [Feature #11003](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11003)
- [x] Integer#allbits?, Integer#anybits?, Integer#nobits? [Feature #12753](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12753)
- [x] Integer.sqrt  [Feature #13219](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13219)

Kernel

- [x] Kernel#yield_self   [Feature #6721](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/6721)
- [x] Kernel#pp  [Feature #14123](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/14123)

Method

Module

Numeric

Process

Range

  [Feature #7688](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/7688)

Regexp

- [x] Support absent operator https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/issues/82
- [x] Support new 5 emoji-related Unicode character properties

String

- [x] #586 String#-@ deduplicates unfrozen strings.  Already-frozen
  strings remain unchanged for compatibility.  [Feature #13077](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13077)
- [x] -"literal" (String#-@) optimized to return the same object
  (same as "literal".freeze in Ruby 2.1+) [Feature #13295](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13295)
- [x] String#{casecmp,casecmp?} return nil for non-string arguments
  instead of raising a TypeError. [Bug #13312](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13312)
- [x] #551 String#start_with? accepts a regexp [Feature #13712](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13712)
- [x] String#delete_prefix, String#delete_prefix! [Feature #12694](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12694)
- [x] String#delete_suffix, String#delete_suffix! [Feature #13665](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13665)
- [x] String#each_grapheme_cluster and String#grapheme_clusters to
  enumerate grapheme clusters [Feature #13780](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13780)
- [x] String#undump to unescape String#dump'ed string [Feature #12275](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12275)

Struct

- [x] Struct.new takes `keyword_init: true` option to initialize members
  with keyword arguments. [Feature #11925](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11925)

- [x] Regexp/String: Update Unicode version from 9.0.0 to 10.0.0 [Feature #13685](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13685)

Thread

- [x] Thread#fetch  [Feature #13009](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13009)
- [x] The default of Thread.report_on_exception is now true,
  showing unhandled exceptions terminating threads on $stderr.
  [Feature #14143](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/14143)

Time

- [x] Time#at receives 3rd argument which specifies the unit of 2nd argument.
  [Feature #13919](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13919)

KeyError

- [x] #574 KeyError#receiver [Feature #12063](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12063)
- [x] #574 KeyError#key      [Feature #12063](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/12063)

FrozenError

- [x] #568 New exception class. [Feature #13224](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13224)

### Stdlib updates

Only stdlib which do not have tests are listed.
Many stdlib live in their own projects with their own tests.

RbConfig

  This is available when rbconfig/sizeof is loaded.

### Compatibility issues (excluding feature bug fixes)

Socket

mathn.rb

- [x] 49cdeadf451a54151d25ad5db11b234d87accf90 82145c5b8430e3a1b57b05ec3334e9b4c4f1106d Removed from stdlib. [Feature #10169](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/10169)

issue.body:
This bug tracks the remaining items from CRuby 2.5's NEWS file that we have not yet implemented in JRuby.

This issue will track Ruby 2.5 support for JRuby. This will be released in JRuby 9.3.0.0 or JRuby 10.

As with previous releases, we will base our checklist on MRI's NEWS file: https://github.com/ruby/ruby/blob/trunk/NEWS
This bug will track all NEWS items new in Ruby 2.5. This list is based off https://github.com/ruby/ruby/blob/trunk/NEWS.

Only changes relevant to JRuby are listed here. MRI-specific internal changes and features are not included.

### Language changes

#### Range

- [x] `Range#initialize` no longer rescue exceptions when comparing begin and
    end with `#<=>` and raise a "bad value for range" ArgumentError
    but instead let the exception from the `#<=>` call go through.
    [Feature #7688](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/7688)

#### Regexp

- [ ] Update to Onigmo 6.1.1.
- [x] Support absent operator https://github.com/k-takata/Onigmo/issues/82

### Compatibility issues (excluding feature bug fixes)

#### BasicSocket

- [ ] `BasicSocket#read_nonblock` and `BasicSocket#write_nonblock` no longer sets the O_NONBLOCK file description flag as side effect (on Linux only) [Feature #13362](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13362)
### Implementation improvements

(Probably not JRuby-relevant.)

  hash function is now SipHash13. [Feature #13017](https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/13017)

issue.title: Matching on streams
issue.body:
Hi there,

Thanks for the cool work on Onigmo!

How hard would it be to extend this library to support matching on arbitrary streams, instead of strings? I'm looking for an equivalent of TRE's [`tre_reguexec`](http://laurikari.net/tre/documentation/reguexec/).

The basic idea is that the caller can pass the equivalent of an iterator over something that may not be a string.  This would make it possible to match over gap buffers, ropes, piece tables, and other string implementations that do not rely on a contiguous char array.

Thanks!

comments.body: I think this is useful, but unfortunately I don't think it's easy to implement in Onigmo.

Do you think it would be easier to add a limited form of this which supports passing the subject string as an array of strings? Onigmo would consider that as just one string, ignoring the fact that it's split up.  This should provide reasonable efficiently, while being a bit simpler to implement, maybe?

Even simpler, how hard would it be to support just two such strings? This would allow Onigmo to work for gap buffers.

timeline.body: I think this is useful, but unfortunately I don't think it's easy to implement in Onigmo.
